Question_1.Context: Autocrine motility factor (AMF) is a protein that can influence cancer cell behavior by promoting cell motility. It can also be internalized into cells through specific pathways.
Question_1.Question: What is the role of autocrine motility factor (AMF) in cancer cell behavior?
Question_1.C: Has no effect on cell motility
Question_1.Source: Cancer cells employ the secretion of AMF to boost their motility and proliferation through autocrine mechanisms, while also promoting angiogenesis and metastasis via both autocrine and paracrine pathways.

Question_2.Context: Glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (GPI) can exist in different forms, each with distinct functions in cellular processes.
Question_2.Question: What dual role does glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (GPI) play in cellular processes?
Question_2.Source: In its dimeric form, GPI acts as an enzyme, facilitating the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to fructose-6-phosphate, a critical step in glycolysis. However, when existing as a monomer, GPI assumes the functions of AMF and neuroleukin.

Question_3.Context: The pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) is a metabolic pathway parallel to glycolysis. It generates ribose and NADPH and is involved in various aspects of cancer cell behavior.
Question_3.Question: What is the role of the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) in cancer cell behavior?
Question_3.C: It is involved in survival, migration, angiogenesis, proliferation, and metastasis
Question_3.D: It has no role in cancer cell behavior
Question_3.Source: G6PD, a crucial enzyme within the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), is responsible for generating ribose and NADPH. It plays a critical role in regulating various aspects of cancer cell behavior, including survival, migration, angiogenesis, proliferation, and metastasis.

Question_4.Context: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are chemically reactive molecules containing oxygen. They are known to play a role in cell signaling and homeostasis.
Question_4.Question: What effect does an increase in reactive oxygen species (ROS) typically have on cancer cells?
Question_4.D: Has no effect on the cells
Question_4.Source: D-AMF effectively downregulated the expression of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) at both the mRNA and protein levels, resulting in a concurrent increase in the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS).

Question_5.Context: Curcumin is a compound derived from the rhizomes of Curcuma longa L. and is known for its various biological properties.
Question_5.Question: What are the known effects of curcumin?
Question_5.Source: Curcumin, derived from the rhizomes of Curcuma longa L., possesses a wide range of valuable properties, encompassing anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antioxidant effects.

Question_6.Context: The combination of different therapeutic agents can sometimes result in a synergistic effect, enhancing the efficacy against cancer cells.
Question_6.Question: What is the potential benefit of combining curcumin with other therapeutic agents in cancer treatment?
Question_6.Source: Furthermore, there is a growing interest in the synergistic effects of curcumin when combined with established cancer drugs in clinical settings.

Question_7.Context: Inhibiting the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) within the pentose phosphate pathway can influence the resistance of cancer cells to anticancer drugs.
Question_7.Question: Why is inhibiting G6PD considered a strategy to enhance the susceptibility of cancer cells to anticancer drugs?
Question_7.A: It increases the production of ribose
Question_7.B: It reduces the generation of NADPH
Question_7.Source: Consequently, inhibiting G6PD has been documented to enhance the susceptibility of cancer cells to anticancer drugs that induce oxidative stress.

Question_8.Context: Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) is an enzyme involved in the glycolytic pathway and is often used as a reference in experiments.
Question_8.Question: What is the role of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) in cancer?
Question_8.A: It is only a housekeeping enzyme with no role in cancer
Question_8.B: Its overexpression is associated with the development of various cancers
Question_8.C: It inhibits the proliferation of cancer cells
Question_8.D: It is a receptor for cancer drugs
Question_8.Source: Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), a pivotal enzyme responsible for converting NAD+ to NADH within the glycolytic pathway, is considered a housekeeping enzyme and a standard internal reference in Western blotting experiments. However, its overexpression has been associated with the development of various cancers, including CRC.

Question_9.Context: The internalization of autocrine motility factor (AMF) into cancer cells involves specific receptors and pathways.
Question_9.Question: Through which pathway is autocrine motility factor (AMF) internalized into cancer cells?
Question_9.Source: AMF triggers the activation of PI3K/AKT and/or MAPK/ERK signaling pathways and is internalized into the endoplasmic reticulum through an AMF receptor (AMFR)-mediated, dynamin-dependent, cholesterol-sensitive raft pathway.

Question_10.Context: Cell competition is a process that can influence the fate of cells, including cancer cells, by assessing cellular fitness.
Question_10.Question: What is the significance of cell competition in the context of cancer progression?
Question_10.A: It promotes the survival of the fittest cells
Question_10.B: It has no impact on cancer progression
Question_10.C: It decreases the motility of cancer cells
Question_10.D: It increases the genetic diversity of cancer cells
Question_10.Source: Cell competition, positioned as a downstream process within developmental signaling pathways, plays a pivotal role in assessing cellular fitness and selectively eliminating less fit cells.
